title: Global Economy - South China Morning Post
description: Global economy news, including budgets, stock markets and analysis.

items.title: China’s drug and medical device sector emerges as new engine of economic growth
items.creator: Daniel Ren
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s drug and medical device sector emerges as new engine of economic growth

images.alt: Innovative efforts by biotech firms align with Beijing’s ambitions to build China into a technology powerhouse. Photo: Xinhua
images.title: Innovative efforts by biotech firms align with Beijing’s ambitions to build China into a technology powerhouse. Photo: Xinhua

items.content:
China’s pharmaceutical industry, whose revenue is projected to rise by 50 per cent between 2024 and 2030, has emerged as a new growth engine for the national economy as leading players ramp up investment in research and production.
The country’s drug and medical device businesses were forecast to top US$2.1 trillion in revenue by 2030 and US$3.2 trillion annually by 2050, according to estimates by UBS. In 2024, the sector generated about US$1.4 trillion in sales.
“An ageing population offers the...

items.title: US’ Venezuela raid shows geopolitics is now a contest between economic blocs
items.creator: Albert Bakhtizin
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: US’ Venezuela raid shows geopolitics is now a contest between economic blocs
items.content:
The latest developments in Venezuela are interpreted as part of a broader US strategy to secure access to major oil resources. They are much more than that: the US raid signals a transformation in the global economy wherein a country’s power is increasingly determined not by its political actions, but by its capacity to embed resource wealth within a self-sustaining production system.
These deeper processes did not begin today, but rather around 2008-2009 when, according to an integrated...

items.title: Chinese electric vehicle makers set to ‘crack open’ Western markets as trade barriers fall
items.creator: Daniel Ren
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Chinese electric vehicle makers set to ‘crack open’ Western markets as trade barriers fall

images.alt: Electric vehicles for export are seen at a port in Hangzhou, in eastern China’s Zhejiang province on April 2, 2025. Photo: AFP
images.title: Electric vehicles for export are seen at a port in Hangzhou, in eastern China’s Zhejiang province on April 2, 2025. Photo: AFP

items.content:
This year is likely to be a watershed one for the global drive by Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers, as more Western countries open up their markets to high-performance made-in-China models.
Despite low expectations for a hefty jump in overseas sales, EV assemblers like BYD and Geely are expected to get off to a strong start in some of their untapped markets, honing their image as world leaders in terms of production and technology before establishing a long-term foothold, according to...

items.title: China’s cosmetics brands, stepping out of K-beauty’s shadow, set sights on global markets
items.creator: Yeon Woo Lee
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s cosmetics brands, stepping out of K-beauty’s shadow, set sights on global markets
items.content:
Like many of her classmates, Xie Roumei, a 28-year-old accountant from China’s Fujian province, started using South Korean cosmetics in high school – a preference she carried into her twenties.
Most of the eye make-up and beauty products she uses are still Korean, Xie said – a loyalty that has helped turn its cosmetics industry into a global powerhouse, with exports rivalling those of semiconductors and cars.
Fuelled by the global appeal of K-pop, K-dramas and the “glass skin” ideal, the...

items.title: As Trump urges cap on credit card rates, could China follow suit for online loans?
items.creator: Sylvia Ma
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: As Trump urges cap on credit card rates, could China follow suit for online loans?
items.content:
US President Donald Trump’s call for American credit card interest rates to be capped at 10 per cent for a year has sparked a debate in China about whether Beijing should impose a similar limit on online loans.
The discussion comes as many in China – especially younger people – are being enticed by credit offers amid a weak job market and a boom in online loan services.
“Apps now keep luring young people into borrowing,” a finance blogger with nearly 500,000 followers wrote in a social media...

items.title: Key voices missing in chorus of criticism of Trump’s destructive actions
items.creator: Anthony Rowley
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Key voices missing in chorus of criticism of Trump’s destructive actions

images.alt: A cap embroidered with a slogan reading ‘Now it’s NUUK!’ and ‘Make America go away’ is displayed for sale in Copenhagen on January 13. Photo: EPA
images.title: A cap embroidered with a slogan reading ‘Now it’s NUUK!’ and ‘Make America go away’ is displayed for sale in Copenhagen on January 13. Photo: EPA

items.content:
Amid the rising chorus of criticism of US President Donald Trump and his administration’s egregious policy actions, the voices of multilateral institutions have been sadly muted. These internationally owned and supposedly independent bodies appear to be running scared of losing their access to US funding, but the greater risk for them is a loss of credibility if they continue with this cautious approach.
By contrast, the heads of a dozen or so central banks have summoned sufficient courage to...

items.title: Scam and corruption cases spark debate in China over cryptocurrencies’ future
items.creator: Kandy Wong
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Scam and corruption cases spark debate in China over cryptocurrencies’ future
items.content:
The seizure of enormous cryptocurrency caches in two high-profile criminal cases in China – a former head of the central bank’s digital currency research institute accused of corruption, and an alleged scam centre kingpin linked to about US$15 billion in bitcoin – have sparked questions in the country about the safety and future of virtual money.
But analysts said the long-term trend for the assets, especially bitcoin, depended on institutional capital, interest rate expectations and the...

items.title: AI is reshaping US-China tech race – can electricity tilt the balance?
items.creator: Luna Sun,Themis Qi,Zhang Shidong
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: AI is reshaping US-China tech race – can electricity tilt the balance?
items.content:
China’s state-owned power grid giant has pledged to increase fixed-asset investment by 40 per cent over the next five years, at a time when some analysts view electricity capacity as a strategic asset in the US-China rivalry amid soaring demand from artificial intelligence (AI) and other power-hungry industries.
The State Grid Corporation of China expects the investment amount to reach 4 trillion yuan (US$574 billion) through 2030, a company record, as it accelerates efforts to build a “new-type...

items.title: China dumps more US debt, buys other assets as Trump targets Powell
items.creator: Xinyi Wu
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China dumps more US debt, buys other assets as Trump targets Powell
items.content:
China trimmed its holdings of US Treasuries in November to the lowest level since 2008, diverging from a global trend that saw total foreign ownership of the debt instruments hit a record high.
Analysts say the prospect of a politicised Federal Reserve chairmanship under Donald Trump’s presidency has deepened Beijing’s concerns over its exposure to American debt, with more cuts expected.
Beijing’s stockpile fell to US$682.6 billion in November, down from US$688.7 billion in October, according to...

items.title: TSMC buys up land in Arizona as Taiwan pledges US$500 billion US tech investment
items.creator: Ralph Jennings
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: TSMC buys up land in Arizona as Taiwan pledges US$500 billion US tech investment
items.content:
Taiwan has committed to driving hundreds of billions of dollars of extra investment into America’s chip industry as part of a US trade deal announced on Thursday, with the island’s biggest semiconductor producer already moving to buy more land in the US state of Arizona.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) – the world’s largest contract chipmaker – confirmed on Thursday that it had bought a second tract of land in Arizona. The 365-hectare (901-acre) plot nearly doubles the...

items.title: Canada, China hit reset button on relations with tariff agreement
items.creator: Ji Siqi,Sylvia Ma,Dewey Sim
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Canada, China hit reset button on relations with tariff agreement
items.content:
China and Canada have agreed to remove the triple-digit tariffs imposed on each other’s imports – a major thaw in relations after years of icy diplomatic and trade ties – as Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney wrapped up his state visit in Beijing.
Canada will remove the additional 100 per cent in tariffs it had levied on Chinese electric vehicle (EV) imports – imposed in 2024 following a similar move from the United States – while China will lower its tariffs on Canadian canola, Carney said on...

items.title: China’s slowing growth, bilateral tensions top American business concerns in 2026
items.creator: Ralph Jennings
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s slowing growth, bilateral tensions top American business concerns in 2026
items.content:
Concerns about China’s slowing economic growth and “strained” Beijing-Washington relations rank as the top two concerns among members of the American Chamber of Commerce in China this year, according to a chamber survey released on Friday.
The growth concern was raised by 64 per cent of the 368 respondents, making it the leading issue, the annual China Business Climate Survey found.
Fifty-two per cent of respondents reported being profitable or very profitable last year, 6 percentage points more...

items.title: China’s Zhejiang targets 3- to 7-nanometre AI chip breakthroughs to counter US chokehold
items.creator: Frank Chen
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s Zhejiang targets 3- to 7-nanometre AI chip breakthroughs to counter US chokehold
items.content:
China’s eastern tech powerhouse Zhejiang, home to giants like Alibaba and the humanoid robotics start-up Unitree, has set clear targets to develop cutting-chips and chipmaking equipment over the next five years.
The province is the latest locality to prioritise innovation under its new five-year plan. It joins other hubs, including Shenzhen and Shanghai, that have thrown their weight behind Beijing’s nationwide strategy to develop indigenous technologies amid an intensifying rivalry with the...

items.title: Nexperia and Chinese owner fight for control of chipmaker in Dutch court
items.creator: Xiaofei Xu
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Nexperia and Chinese owner fight for control of chipmaker in Dutch court
items.content:
The battle for control of Dutch chipmaker Nexperia entered a new phase on Wednesday, as lawyers representing the firm and its Chinese parent Wingtech Technology traded blows during a seven-hour court hearing in the Netherlands.
The Enterprise Chamber – a special Dutch court handling corporate disputes – scheduled the hearing to determine whether it should order a formal investigation into alleged mismanagement at Nexperia or overturn its earlier ruling, with a verdict set to be issued by...

items.title: China’s C919 airliner put through paces by test pilots from European aviation regulator
items.creator: Frank Chen
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s C919 airliner put through paces by test pilots from European aviation regulator
items.content:
European aviation evaluators have begun test flights of China’s home-grown C919 airliner in Shanghai, the Post has learned, as the manufacturer of the narrowbody jet presses ahead with its bid to secure Western safety certification – a crucial step in the journey to global adoption and being able to compete with industry leaders Boeing and Airbus.
Two test pilots from the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) have conducted verification flights, according to a source with knowledge of the...

items.title: China-EU tariff agreement on EVs seen cutting shipments but boosting profitability (原标题: China-EU tariff consensus on EVs seen cutting shipments but boosting profitability)
items.creator: Daniel Ren
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China-EU tariff agreement on EVs seen cutting shipments but boosting profitability
items.content:
A requirement to set minimum prices for their cars in the European Union will reduce sales there for Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers, but higher profit margins will eventually improve their bottom lines and brand reputations, according to analysts and industry officials.
Assemblers of Chinese pure-electric cars from BYD to Leapmotor will avoid a brutal discount war after European authorities accepted price undertakings to replace punitive anti-subsidy tariffs of up to 35.3 per cent.
Minimum...

items.title: Why China may buy Nvidia’s H200 chips as Trump eases curbs – and replace them later
items.creator: Ralph Jennings,Kandy Wong
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Why China may buy Nvidia’s H200 chips as Trump eases curbs – and replace them later
items.content:
China is likely to accept Nvidia’s H200 artificial intelligence (AI) chips following US clearance, driven by immediate demand in the country’s vast tech sector, according to analysts – though they said Beijing would push to replace them over time.
The American chip giant’s second-most-advanced AI processor can be exported to China from Thursday, as long as shipments total no more than half the amount sold in the US, according to the Department of Commerce’s Bureau of Industry and...

items.title: ‘Structurally hurt’: why are Chinese tourists spending less overseas than before?
items.creator: Yeon Woo Lee
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: ‘Structurally hurt’: why are Chinese tourists spending less overseas than before?
items.content:
Chinese tourist numbers are recovering across Asia after a pandemic-era contraction, buoyed by the expansion of visa-free policies and a stronger yuan. But one thing has not returned: the spending sprees that used to boost duty-free retailers around the world.
The trend can be clearly seen in South Korea, which relied on Chinese travellers for 70 per cent of its duty-free sales before Covid-19. Around 5 million visitors from China arrived in the country during the first 11 months of 2025, a...

items.title: The AI boom needs electricity, but Western grids are strained. Is power China’s power?
items.creator: Xiaofei Xu,Kandy Wong
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: The AI boom needs electricity, but Western grids are strained. Is power China’s power?
items.content:
Near the end of last year, thousands of European travellers saw their holiday plans unravel after a prolonged power outage in the Eurotunnel – the underwater train passage linking Britain and France – caused by a fault in the overhead supply.
For many, this brought back memories of chaotic scenes the previous April, when rolling blackouts struck much of Portugal and Spain. The United States also suffered from multiple power outages last year, including major disruptions in California – most...

items.title: China, Canada poised to reset trade ties after Trump’s tariffs force rethink
items.creator: Ralph Jennings,Kandy Wong
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China, Canada poised to reset trade ties after Trump’s tariffs force rethink
items.content:
Canada and China appear ready to kick-start trade talks after years of strained relations, with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney’s visit to Beijing this week coinciding with both countries questioning their once stronger ties with the United States, analysts said.
Carney travelled to Beijing on Tuesday for his first official visit to the country, where he will discuss trade, agriculture and energy with officials from Canada’s second-largest single-country trading partner.
Liang Yan, a...
